content.raw: sounds similar to what [gluLookAt](https://www.opengl.org/sdk/docs/man2/xhtml/gluLookAt.xml) does. LookAt functions are quite common in rendering, e.g. also [ogre](http://www.ogre3d.org/docs/api/1.9/class_ogre_1_1_camera.html#a54542bfe56c8a09949d35d6c75a5045c). Is it similar to what you're doing?
content.html: sounds similar to what gluLookAt does. LookAt functions are quite common in rendering, e.g. also ogre. Is it similar to what you're doing?

content.raw:
The use case is similar, but the API has 2 main differences from `glu`:

1. The implementation here is simpler, because you can't specify the up vector (it's always +Z)
1. Instead of an "eye position", here we give a "direction" (or as @scpeters suggested, an "observer offset"). I think there are use cases for both, if you know the eye's position and just want to rotate it to face the target, the `glu` approach is more convenient. Here, I basically copied a chunk of code which we're [repeatedly](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1998/duplicate-angle-math-calculations) using in Gazebo. It looks like our main use case starts from not knowing the eye position, but I haven't looked at all the cases. It could be interesting to have both functions here, I can implement them if we agree on the API.

The Ogre API also assumes we know the position and just changes orientation to face a point.
content.html:
The use case is similar, but the API has 2 main differences from glu:

  1. The implementation here is simpler, because you can't specify the up vector (it's always +Z)
  2. Instead of an "eye position", here we give a "direction" (or as @scpeters suggested, an "observer offset"). I think there are use cases for both, if you know the eye's position and just want to rotate it to face the target, the glu approach is more convenient. Here, I basically copied a chunk of code which we're repeatedly using in Gazebo. It looks like our main use case starts from not knowing the eye position, but I haven't looked at all the cases. It could be interesting to have both functions here, I can implement them if we agree on the API.

The Ogre API also assumes we know the position and just changes orientation to face a point.

How about something like this:

1. The current function with up direction added:

    `static Pose3<T> MoveToLookAt(const Vector3<T> &_target, const Vector3<T> &_lookDirection, const Vector3<T> &_upDirection = Vector3<T>::UnitZ)`

1. Add a function to rotate in place:

    `Pose3<T> RotateToLookAt(const Vector3<T> &_target, const Vector3<T> &_upDirection = Vector3<T>::UnitZ)`
content.html:
How about something like this:

  1. The current function with up direction added:

    static Pose3<T> MoveToLookAt(const Vector3<T> &_target, const Vector3<T> &_lookDirection, const Vector3<T> &_upDirection = Vector3<T>::UnitZ)

  2. Add a function to rotate in place:

    Pose3<T> RotateToLookAt(const Vector3<T> &_target, const Vector3<T> &_upDirection = Vector3<T>::UnitZ)

content.raw: Sounds good to me. As @scpeters suggested, how about calling it an `offset` instead of `_lookDirection`?

content.raw: I'm having mixed feelings about this. Not sure what the best name is, but with the current implementation `offset` doesn't seem to describe the behaviour. What does it mean if you give it an `offset` of `UnitZ`? The current implementation would rotate `UnitX` to match `UnitZ`. Is that what one would expect? Maybe we should change the implementation as well...
content.html: I'm having mixed feelings about this. Not sure what the best name is, but with the current implementation offset doesn't seem to describe the behaviour. What does it mean if you give it an offset of UnitZ? The current implementation would rotate UnitX to match UnitZ. Is that what one would expect? Maybe we should change the implementation as well...

content.raw:
Nice! That looks great.

I'm confused about the up parameter though. I thought the camera wasn't supposed to roll, but it seemed to do so in the video?
content.html:
Nice! That looks great.

I'm confused about the up parameter though. I thought the camera wasn't supposed to roll, but it seemed to do so in the video?

content.raw:
Now the implementation has an optional `_up` vector, which is `UnitZ` by default. If you specify `UnitY` as your up vector for example, the camera needs to roll.

The up vector is mostly a suggestion though, because in several cases it is not possible to keep it and at the same time keep looking at the target. In the demo, that is demonstrated by the semi-transparent blue cylinder, which diverges from the frame's Z axis, for example, when you need a pitch to tilt the camera.
content.html:
Now the implementation has an optional _up vector, which is UnitZ by default. If you specify UnitY as your up vector for example, the camera needs to roll.

The up vector is mostly a suggestion though, because in several cases it is not possible to keep it and at the same time keep looking at the target. In the demo, that is demonstrated by the semi-transparent blue cylinder, which diverges from the frame's Z axis, for example, when you need a pitch to tilt the camera.

content.raw:
I'm thinking of an easy way of explaining it. I think an image speaks much better than words:

![lookatz.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/dg5enz/images/3455036160-lookatz.png)

`_up` is the desired direction for the camera's Z, expressed in the world frame. Here it is about [0, -1, 1] and represented by the semi-transparent blue cylinder. It isn't possible to put the camera's Z there and still keep looking (point the camera's X) at the target. So we do our best by at least keeping the camera's left (Y) the same it would be with our desired `_up`. Oh so many words!
content.html:
I'm thinking of an easy way of explaining it. I think an image speaks much better than words:

_up is the desired direction for the camera's Z, expressed in the world frame. Here it is about [0, -1, 1] and represented by the semi-transparent blue cylinder. It isn't possible to put the camera's Z there and still keep looking (point the camera's X) at the target. So we do our best by at least keeping the camera's left (Y) the same it would be with our desired _up. Oh so many words!

I think the implementation is generic enough that _up can be any vector. The description describes the default case if _up is not specified right?

Something like this?

      /// \brief Get transform where the translation is _eye, and the rotation
      /// orients the _eye to face the _target. If _up is not specified, the 
      /// X axis gets rotated towards _target, while keeping the Z axis towards 
      ///_up, if possible.

Oh yeah it would be nice to mention the default values. As for orients the _eye to face the _target, _eye is a point, so it has no orientation. Maybe we can say it rotates the frame so its X axis faces the target? How about this:

      /// \brief Get transform which translates to _eye and rotates the X axis
      /// so it faces the _target. The rotation is such that Z axis is in the _up direction, if possible.
      /// \param[in] _eye Coordinate frame translation.
      /// \param[in] _target Point which the X axis should face. If _target is equal to _eye, 
      /// the X axis won't be rotated.
      /// \param[in] _up Direction in which the Z axis should point. If _up is zero or parallel to X,
      /// it will be set to +Z.

content.raw: ya the concern I had was about saying that X is forward and Z is up. I was hoping it could be more generic. If I am writing a computer graphics application where the standard up is +Y and forward is +Z, I am still able to use this function in a way that doesn't match the description in `\brief`.
content.html: ya the concern I had was about saying that X is forward and Z is up. I was hoping it could be more generic. If I am writing a computer graphics application where the standard up is +Y and forward is +Z, I am still able to use this function in a way that doesn't match the description in \brief.

content.raw: The current implementation assumes X is forward, there's no way around that at the moment.
content.html: The current implementation assumes X is forward, there's no way around that at the moment.
